proposals.reasoning: Most of the table seems comfortable with an Alice + Frank core, and this version adds Diana as a third to avoid auto-locking the same Bob/Jack slot that’s been in nearly every suggested variant. This gives us a clean, relatively low-drama Mission 1 while deliberately leaving both Bob and Jack off so we can later compare how teams with and without them perform. It also spreads early information across talkative and quieter players without stacking all the loudest voices together on the very first mission.

votes.comment: I’m on the team, and a Mission 1 success with this low-suspicion trio will build trust and useful future leverage without exposing any teammate.
Reasonable M1 info team with widely supported Alice+Frank core; fine staying off early while we gather data.
Reasonable low-info M1 team with broadly supported Alice+Frank core; fine to get an early data point without overengineering.
Solid, commonly supported Alice+Frank core plus me; no strong early red flags and Mission 1 should prioritize gathering info over deep suspicion.
Early mission with no info; Alice+Frank core was widely supported and including Diana instead of auto‑locking Bob/Jack gives us a useful comparison point later.
Mission 1 with me + Alice is broadly supported and Diana is a reasonable third; no strong red flags yet and we need early mission data more than we need to over-optimize the first team.
No known evils on this team and it avoids the Bob/Jack slot, giving us a clean baseline for Mission 1.
I was already leaning toward Alice + Frank plus one of Bob/Jack; sidelining both Bob and Jack here feels like worse early info and slightly forced away from the table’s initial consensus.
Mission 1 with Alice + Frank core is broadly supported and low-risk; adding Diana instead of Bob/Jack gives us a clean info baseline without obvious red flags yet.
Solid Alice+Frank core that most of the table likes, plus only one of my known evil teammates on it; good for generating early info without exposing me and Bob.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d lean toward a low‑drama, test team like Bob and Charlie plus one of the early leaders, just so we get some clean voting and mission data to work with. I’m flexible on whether I’m on it, but I’d rather avoid stacking it with all the loudest voices right away.

I like the idea of a “low‑drama” first team, but I’d slightly prefer spreading trust by not auto-including only the first speakers—something like Alice, Charlie, and Frank feels like a reasonable baseline test. If people are uncomfortable with that, I’m fine swapping myself in for any one of them so we at least see how the table reacts to the proposal.

I’m fine with a “low‑drama” opener, but I’d rather not lock in too many early talkers together—something like Alice, Frank, and one of Bob/Jack (instead of me) feels like a cleaner spread of info to start.

I’d rather keep the very first team pretty balanced and not overfit it to the early talkers—something like Alice, Frank, and Jack works for me, and I’m fine staying off so we get to see that trio’s mission result and everyone’s votes on it.

I’d like to avoid auto-locking Alice + Frank + Jack just because they were named first—something like Alice, Frank, and one of Bob/Charlie feels like a good balance of info without overcommitting to the same trio.
I’m okay being on the first team, but I’d slightly prefer Alice + me + Bob over Alice + me + Jack so we’re not just auto-accepting the earliest-named trio and we still get a solid info spread.

I’d rather start with a trio that hasn’t been name‑checked in every variant so far—something like Alice, Frank, and Diana gives us a clean spread without overfitting to the same Bob/Jack slot every time. I’m not hard opposed to Bob or Jack later, but I’d like at least one mission 1 without either so we have a clearer comparison point.
I’m fine with the Alice + Frank core, but I’d slightly rather see one of Bob/Jack fill the third slot instead of Diana so we don’t completely sideline both of them from Mission 1’s info and voting.

I’d lean toward Alice + Frank + Bob as a reasonable compromise that fits most of what’s been suggested so far. I’d rather not have both Bob and Jack completely off the first mission, just so we’re not flying blind on two big question marks.

I’m pretty comfortable with an Alice + Frank + Bob first team—it lines up with most of the table’s instincts and gives us solid info without overengineering Mission 1. If people are nervous about Bob, I’d be fine with swapping me in for him, but I don’t see a strong reason to deviate yet.

proposals.reasoning: I’m keeping exactly two members from the successful first mission (Alice and Frank) to preserve continuity from a clean result while not assuming all three were good. I’m adding myself (Henry) so my alignment becomes testable instead of staying on the sidelines. For the final slot I’m choosing Bob over Charlie to avoid the Bob+Charlie pairing that several people flagged as premature, while still getting new information on a widely suggested candidate. This team balances proven-ish members with fresh info and aligns with the majority’s stated preferences from discussion, which should help it get approved and give us strong alignment data for future missions.

votes.comment: Keeps two from the clean first mission while adding two widely discussed but untested players, which should give strong info regardless of the result.
It keeps two from the successful first mission while adding two new people for info, and most of the table’s preferences converged on something close to this lineup.
Team fits the consensus logic of keeping two from the clean Mission 1 and adding two widely discussed new players; nothing here stands out as risky enough to justify blocking it this early.

This matches my earlier preference for keeping Alice and Frank and adding Bob; swapping in Henry instead of Charlie is reasonable and gets good info on two new players without straying far from the table’s consensus.
Good continuity with 2 from the successful first mission plus two commonly suggested new players; solid info-gathering lineup this early.

Team keeps 2 from the clean first mission (Alice, me) and tests two new players (Henry, Bob). It’s a broadly discussed structure and gives strong info even if it fails, so I’m fine approving this early-game.

I don’t like adding only one totally untested player when we have a clean mission to lean on; I’d rather swap Bob for Diana to keep 3 from the successful team before we start mixing in too many unknowns.
Keeps two from a clean team, includes myself for alignment info, and only introduces one completely unknown (Bob); statistically and informationally this is a solid early-game team.
Keeps two from the clean first mission while testing two widely discussed new players; reasonable risk/reward for Mission 2 information gain.
Two known evils (Alice and Bob) are on this team with me off it, giving us a strong chance to sabotage Mission 2 while keeping my alignment untested.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d like to keep at least two of Alice/Frank/Diana on the team, and then add one of the quieter folks like Bob or Charlie so we start getting information on new people without throwing out what just worked.

I like the idea of keeping some continuity from the first team, but not all three—maybe two of Alice/Frank/Diana plus two new faces (I’d volunteer myself and maybe Charlie) so we’re mixing proven-ish players with fresh info.
I’m fine being the “new info” here, but I’d rather not lock in all three from the first team—something like Alice + Diana + Bob + me feels like a good balance of continuity and fresh reads.

I’m on board with keeping exactly two from the first team, but I’d prefer we don’t drop Frank automatically—something like Alice + Frank + Bob + Charlie feels like a good mix of continuity and new info.

I’d also lean toward keeping exactly two from the first team, and I slightly prefer Alice + Frank + Bob + Charlie so we’re testing two new people while still anchoring on folks who just passed a mission.

I definitely want at least two from the first team again, and I lean toward keeping myself on as one of them—something like Alice + Frank + Bob + Charlie feels like a good mix of continuity and new info without overhauling what just worked.

I’m on board with keeping exactly two from the first mission, but I’d rather not pair Bob and Charlie together just yet—something like Alice, Frank, Henry, plus one of Bob/Charlie feels like a safer way to get new info.

I like the idea of exactly two from the first team, but I’d rather we don’t just auto-lock Bob/Charlie together—something like Alice, Frank, me, plus one of Bob or Charlie feels like a good balance of continuity and fresh info.
I like the “exactly two from the first team” idea, and I’d lean toward Alice + Frank + Bob + one of Charlie/Henry so we’re building off the clean result while still getting solid new info.

I’d also stick with exactly two from the first mission, and right now Alice + Frank + Henry + Bob feels like a solid mix of proven-ish players and one newer read without doubling up too hard on the Bob/Charlie combo yet.

proposals.reasoning: I’m building around the consensus Diana–Charlie–Eve core that avoids the double‑fail overlap of Henry and Bob entirely, while still anchoring on someone from the successful first mission. Taking exactly one of the Mission 2 overlaps (Alice vs. Frank), I’m choosing Alice as the single overlap so we don’t repeat the Alice–Frank–Henry–Bob configuration that gave us two fails, but we still get new information by pairing her with mostly fresh players plus Diana from the clean Mission 1.

votes.comment: Fits the consensus Diana–Charlie–Eve core, avoids the Henry/Bob double-fail pair, and only brings back one overlap from Mission 2 for a cleaner read.
This fits the Diana–Charlie–Eve core I liked, keeps both me and Henry off after the double-fail, and only takes one overlap from Mission 2 for a cleaner read.
This matches the Diana–Charlie–Eve core with exactly one of Alice/Frank that I argued for earlier, and it avoids the Henry/Bob double-fail overlap while giving mostly fresh info.

Best balance so far: excludes highly suspicious Henry/Bob, keeps Diana from clean M1, and uses only one overlap (Alice) from the double-fail team, which limits but doesn’t eliminate risk while giving good info.
Keeps both Henry and Bob (heavily implicated by the double fail) off, only one player from the suspect M2 overlap (Alice), plus two fresh and Diana from the clean M1—solid balance of safety and info.

Best balance so far: fully excludes Henry and Bob, who must contain at least two spies with one of Alice, and only takes one player (Alice) from that contaminated set plus three relatively clean/untested picks headed by Diana from the successful first mission.

I still don’t love including Charlie here when we could run a version anchored more on known quantities like Diana plus Eve and one of {Alice/Frank/me}. I’d prefer a tweak that swaps Charlie out rather than loading this mission on a mostly new read.

Keeps both me and Bob (where we know at least 2 of Alice/Frank/Bob are evil and I’m good) off together, only takes one from that highly suspicious trio (Alice), and pairs her with Diana plus two fresh players for strong info. This matches the structure I advocated earlier.

Best balance so far: fully drops Henry/Bob from the double-fail, uses the widely supported Diana–Charlie–Eve core, and limits Mission 2 overlap to exactly one player (Alice), keeping the risk profile and info gain reasonable.
As evil, I’m happy with this: at least one evil (Alice) is on it, Henry and Bob (suspected by many) are off, and letting it go gives us a good shot at a critical fail on Mission 3.

discussion.content: With two fails on Mission 2, I really don’t want to see both Henry and Bob together on the next team. I’d lean toward bringing back Diana from the clean first mission and adding a couple of people who weren’t on Mission 2 at all.

I’m fine being left off the next team, but we shouldn’t pretend Mission 1 magically cleared anyone—Alice and Frank were on both teams, so for Mission 3 I’d rather see something like Diana + two from {Charlie, Eve, Jack, Grace} and then just one of {Alice, Frank}.

I like the idea of starting from Diana plus a couple of people who haven’t been on any mission yet—something like Diana, me, and one of Eve/Jack—then only *one* of the Mission 2 overlap (Alice or Frank) so we don’t risk another double-fail setup.

I’m on board with building around me plus two fresh faces like Charlie and one of Eve/Jack, and then only *one* of Alice/Frank from the double-fail team. Right now I’d slightly rather test Alice than Frank, but I’m open to hearing if people feel the opposite.

I like the framework of building around Diana plus two fresh players, so something like Diana–Charlie–me and then just one of Alice/Frank, while keeping both Henry and Bob off this mission after that double‑fail.

Given the double-fail on Mission 2, I’d rather we hard-reset and run something like Diana–Charlie–Eve–Jack with *none* of the Mission 2 overlap (including me) so we get a really clean info read. If we *do* take one of Alice/Frank, I’d actually rather you pick Alice and leave me off so my Mission 2 presence doesn’t muddy the waters again.

I like the idea of building around Diana, but I’d rather see something like Diana–Eve–Frank plus one of {Alice/me} and avoid putting both Charlie and Jack into the first “fresh” test at the same time. That keeps us mostly away from the double‑fail overlap while not overloading the team with completely untested players.

Given the double‑fail I’m fine staying off this one with Bob, but I really don’t like loading up on completely fresh players either—something like Diana–Charlie–Eve plus exactly one of Alice/Frank (not both) feels like a reasonable balance of safety and new info.

I’m happiest with the Diana–Charlie–Eve core that several people have floated, plus exactly one of Alice/Frank, and I slightly prefer testing Alice here while keeping both Henry and Bob off after that double‑fail.

I’m good with the Diana–Charlie–Eve core that’s been floated, and I’d slightly rather add Alice than Frank so we keep both Henry and Bob off after that double‑fail. That gives us a mostly fresh look while still anchoring around the clean first mission.

proposals.reasoning: This team fully avoids the double-fail Mission 2 block (Alice, Henry, Bob, Frank), which most of the table has flagged as the highest-risk group. It reuses the Diana/Charlie/Eve core that several players are comfortable with, but balances Eve’s and Frank’s concern about too much overlap by adding Grace and myself instead of anyone from Mission 2. Grace is widely townread off the clean Mission 1, and I’m willing to be tested here as a fresh slot with no direct tie to previous fails. If this somehow fails, it gives very clear, focused information on a compact set of suspects without reintroducing the already-problematic Mission 2 players.

votes.comment: This keeps the entire double-fail Mission 2 block off while putting a fresh, high-info lineup on the board that I’ve already said I’m comfortable with.
I’m off the team, it excludes the heavily suspected Mission 2 block, and with only Jack from evil on it there’s a strong chance for an immediate third fail and win.
I want a team that fully dodges the double-fail Mission 2 block, and this fits the consensus shape while giving us fresh info; I’m comfortable being on it.

Best low-overlap team: fully avoids the double-fail Mission 2 block and only reuses the M3 core once, which strongly suspects Alice as the M3 fail. If this fails, suspicion focuses cleanly on the Diana/Charlie/Eve/Grace/Jack group.

I know I’m good, so the Mission 3 fail must be in {Diana, Charlie, Alice}, and Alice is already heavily suspect from the double-fail. That still leaves at least one of Diana/Charlie as a real risk, and I’d rather not run both of them again when we can build around me plus only one of them and safer slots like Grace/Jack/Iris.

Keeps the highly suspicious Mission 2 block (Alice/Henry/Bob plus me) completely off, and if Alice is the likeliest spy on Mission 3 then Diana/Charlie/Eve are probably good, making this lineup our best odds with strong info if it somehow fails.

I’m still uneasy about reusing both Diana and Charlie together right after a fail on Mission 3; I’d prefer a lineup that keeps overlap with that mission lower, closer to the Diana/Eve/Frank/Iris/me shape I mentioned earlier.

Keeps the entire double-fail Mission 2 block (Alice/Bob/Frank plus me) off, and if Alice is the most likely evil from Mission 3, then Diana/Charlie/Eve are probably good, making this team our best shot without reusing the suspicious core.

Team fully avoids the double-fail Mission 2 block and matches the structure Bob (my stronger Merlin read) has been pushing for; despite my preference to be on instead of Charlie, this is likely our highest-percentage low-overlap option now.

Quest 4 needs two fails; with only me from the known evil block on this team, there’s a real risk this succeeds. I’d rather push for a lineup that includes at least one of Alice/Bob to ensure we keep strong fail potential.

discussion.content: Given the double-fail on Mission 2, I really don’t want to reuse that core, so I’d rather build around people like Diana/Charlie/Eve plus someone like Grace or Jack who haven’t been tied to both fails. Keeping overlap between Missions 2 and 3 as low as possible feels safest right now.

Alice has been on both failed missions, so I’d strongly prefer she sit this one out; I’m most comfortable with something like Diana / Charlie / Eve plus Grace and Jack, keeping the Mission 2 overlap as low as possible.
I’m good with a Diana / me / Eve core, and I’d rather fill it out with both Grace and Jack so we completely avoid reusing anyone from the double-fail Mission 2.

I definitely want Alice sitting out after being on both failing teams, and I’d rather avoid anyone from the double‑fail Mission 2 entirely if we can. From my point of view the best shot is something like me / Charlie / Eve / Grace / Jack, with the understanding that if this fails we’re basically forced to look hard at Charlie/Eve.

I agree Alice should sit after being on both fails, but I’m nervous about putting both Diana and Charlie back together when there was only a single fail on Mission 3. I’d rather see something like me / Grace / Jack plus just one of Diana or Charlie, and fill the last spot from outside the Mission 2 group.

From where I’m sitting, we almost certainly have at least one evil in {Alice, Henry, Bob}, with Alice the shadiest after being on both fails, so I’d like a team built around Grace / Jack / Eve plus just one of Diana or Charlie, and I’m fine staying off this one if that helps keep overlap with Mission 2 low.

Given the double‑fail on Mission 2, I really want to keep Alice / Henry / Bob off this team, and I’m also a bit wary of Jack getting a free pass without any concrete track record. I’d lean toward something like Diana / Eve / Frank / Iris / me as a cleaner, lower‑overlap option.

Given the double‑fail on my Mission 2, I really want all of Alice/Bob/Frank (and me) off this one, and I’m especially suspicious of Alice for being on both failing teams. I’d be happiest with something like Diana / Eve / Grace / Jack / Iris or swapping Iris for Charlie if folks really want that Mission 3 overlap.

I really want to keep the double‑fail core (Alice/Henry/Bob/Frank) off this one, so I like the shape of Diana / Eve / Grace / Jack / me as our best low‑overlap, high‑info team. If this still fails, we’ll have a much clearer spotlight on where evil’s hiding.

I’m with the folks who want the whole Alice/Henry/Bob block off after the double‑fail, and I’m fine taking the risk of being on here myself. I’d lean toward something like Diana / Eve / Grace / Charlie / me, since I’m a bit more comfortable testing Charlie than putting Iris back on right after she led a failing team.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted as Mordred, getting on early teams and helping secure key fails without drawing too much suspicion, which let evil control missions 2–4. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around who was suspicious to misdirect Merlin and Percival earlier, instead of relying mainly on quiet reliability.

player_observations.Bob: Leaned into the hidden-threat role well on mission 2, but could sometimes over-participate in accusations, which risked connecting them to other evil players.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very chaotic and hard-to-read game consistent with Oberon, creating background noise that made information harder for good to parse but also harder for evil to coordinate around.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to trust early teams and seemed to rely more on social reads than mechanical logic, which made her a bit easier to keep on misfiring or mixed teams.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and seemed hesitant to hard-push suspicions, which made her appear generally reasonable but also less influential in redirecting teams away from evil.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as straightforward and honest, especially after the clean first mission, which made him a useful ‘clear’ good in table talk that evil could subtly nudge without much pushback.
player_observations.Grace: Her team selections and mission reactions were generally sharp and aligned with hidden information, which made her look like Merlin; she was careful but not quite cautious enough in concealing how accurate her reads were.
player_observations.Henry: As a leader on mission 2, his team choice was somewhat loose, which allowed multiple evil to slip in; overall his decision-making felt more trusting than deductive.
player_observations.Iris: Showed signs of trying to protect and infer Merlin, tracking patterns in Grace’s behavior, but occasionally second-guessed herself and didn’t press her strongest reads hard enough.
player_observations.Jack: Balanced aggression and subtlety well as Assassin, taking in social cues and mission outcomes to narrow Merlin candidates, and was willing to assemble a risky mission 4 that still worked out for evil.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team by getting on the critical Mission 2 fail and staying relatively unsuspicious afterward, letting Mordred and Assassin do a lot of the heavy lifting later. I could have done more active misdirection around Merlin/Perci reads, especially by pushing harder on alternative Merlin candidates once Grace started to look accurate.

player_observations.Alice: Played an effective, low-key Mordred, getting on multiple mission teams and helping secure early and mid-game fails without drawing overwhelming suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, their signals were harder to read, but they still created enough general confusion to keep good from forming a clean consensus.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to project a fairly straightforward good vibe and was trusted enough to be repeatedly included on teams, which unfortunately put her on several failing missions.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and seemed to lean heavily on mission results for reads, which made it harder for her to isolate the hidden evil roles despite being often included.
player_observations.Frank: Looked convincingly good early, especially after the first successful mission, but didn’t manage to convert that into strong late-game leadership or a tight circle of trust.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, she read the board well overall but couldn’t translate her information into strong enough pushes to get consistently safe teams or avoid the Assassin’s endgame shot.
player_observations.Henry: As a leader on Mission 2, he put together a risky team that included multiple evils, and afterward didn’t strongly drive a clear narrative about who should be trusted.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, her protection of Merlin was only partially effective; she had some right instincts but didn’t commit firmly enough to a strong Merlin cover story.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, he benefited from the general confusion and correctly trusted the evil information enough in the endgame to secure the win with the final shot.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile as Oberon, which helped avoid drawing Merlin’s focus and kept suspicion scattered, contributing to the evil team’s overall success. However, I could have been more deliberate in shaping table talk and voting patterns to mislead good players more proactively, rather than mostly reacting to others’ narratives.

player_observations.Alice: Played very assertively and comfortably on teams, and the double-fail on Mission 2 suggests she was willing to take bold risks early to establish confusion. Her presence on multiple missions without getting hard-cleared shows she balanced suspicion and trust well.
player_observations.Bob: Seemed to operate more from the shadows, letting others drive discussion while benefiting from the chaos. His coordination on the failing mission subtly reinforced evil outcomes without loudly tying suspicion back to himself.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as generally trustworthy and willing to go on early missions, which made her a natural candidate for teams. Her inclusion on multiple missions that ended up failing likely put her in a tough spot socially despite playing from a good perspective.
player_observations.Eve: Maintained a relatively calm, good-leaning table presence and was frequently trusted for critical missions. Being on the failing missions without being clearly identified as evil shows she either wasn’t strongly pushing narratives or was overshadowed by louder voices.
player_observations.Frank: Was trusted enough to be included early and on the pivotal Mission 2, which failed with two FAILs. His style seemed cooperative and straightforward, making him look like a safe pick even as he was involved in a key turning point for the game.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, she managed information carefully but didn’t lock onto the full evil team strongly enough to prevent repeated fails. Her reads seemed somewhat scattered, which gave evil room to operate without drawing a decisive assassination risk too early.
player_observations.Henry: Led Mission 2 and chose a team that ended up heavily compromised, which created a lot of noise and suspicion around multiple players. His leadership choices suggested he was trying to play logically, but they inadvertently handed evil a powerful early swing.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she appeared to be juggling conflicting signals about who Merlin was, which blunted good’s ability to consolidate around strong reads. Her uncertainty helped preserve ambiguity around the real information holders.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin and a late leader, he embraced the high-risk, high-impact role by putting together a heavily evil-leaning Mission 4 that sealed the game. His endgame positioning and willingness to stack that mission showed strong confidence in the hidden information flow for team evil.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well staying generally trusted and not attracting heavy suspicion, which helped good secure early mission success and kept lines of communication open. However, I could have pushed harder on questioning the logic behind Mission 2 after the double fail and been more decisive in resisting the Mission 3 and 4 team compositions that kept mixing in hidden evil.

player_observations.Alice: Played very confidently and leaned into early trust, using consistent participation on teams to appear solidly good while quietly anchoring key failed missions.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed relatively low-key but positioned himself on pivotal teams, using quiet agreement and minimal drama to avoid becoming a major suspect despite Mission 2’s double fail.
player_observations.Charlie: Had a somewhat erratic table presence that fit Oberon well—enough confusion and unpredictability that it was hard to read alignment cleanly and easy to dismiss some red flags as just chaos.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as earnest and reasonably analytical, which made her seem like a reliable teammate, but sometimes deferred a bit too much on team selection logic in the later missions.
player_observations.Frank: Gave off a steady, good-leaning vibe and was trusted early, but didn’t heavily drive the narrative after the disastrous Mission 2, which may have let evil shape the conversation more.
player_observations.Grace: Her reasoning was usually coherent and subtly guiding, which fits Merlin, but she stayed cautious enough that her stronger reads on evil didn’t always translate into hard pushes on team composition.
player_observations.Henry: Looked quite good in discussion and voting patterns, but being on the double-fail Mission 2 made him a long-term suspicion point that he didn’t fully shake off with assertive follow-up logic.
player_observations.Iris: Showed signs of trying to protect and mirror Grace’s reads as Percival, but the way those soft defenses and tentative pushes came out sometimes looked like ordinary good uncertainty rather than a strong information-based role.
player_observations.Jack: Played a flexible social game, not overassertive but present enough in discussions, and as Assassin managed to stay plausible as good until the endgame, giving evil a strong position after mission losses.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the early mission 1 team a bit too much and didn’t push hard enough to re-evaluate Alice and Frank after the double-fail on mission 2, which let evil stay comfortably in the "probably good" bucket for too long. I did well staying generally consistent with my voting and arguments so I didn't look chaotic, but I need to be bolder about calling out suspicious patterns and pushing for cleaner, more information-rich team comps earlier.

player_observations.Alice: Very good at looking structurally "safe"—being on mission 1’s success and then blending into larger teams made her feel like default-good even after later fails. She leveraged that early trust to stay off the radar as Mordred, especially since Merlin couldn’t see her.
player_observations.Bob: Played Morgana in a way that likely made them look like a strong information-holder, creating plausible confusion with Merlin. Tended to sit in a mid-accusation zone—suspicious but always with just enough logic to avoid being cleanly excluded.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, their voting and team opinions probably looked a bit off-tempo, which was hard to read as either clueless good or disconnected evil. Their presence on the failed mission 3 and 4 teams added noise without clearly outing them, which is strong for hidden evil.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as fairly trustworthy and willing to go on multiple missions, which is solid for a good player trying to generate information. Might benefit from being a bit louder about pushing people they distrust off critical later missions.
player_observations.Frank: Being on the successful mission 1 and then on the failed mission 2 with multiple fail cards made Frank a tricky read—looked like either a framed good or a quiet evil. Tended to play a low-key style, which is helpful for good when honest but can also make it harder for others to clear them decisively.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, Grace did a good job not being obviously loud or reckless, which likely kept her alive for the assassin shot, but perhaps erred slightly on the side of subtlety. Her team selections and votes suggested some underlying info, yet not enough hard pushes to flip the table away from hidden evil.
player_observations.Henry: As a good player leading mission 2, Henry put together a risky lineup that gave a lot of information but also handed evil a big early win with two fail cards. His choices felt logically structured, but he could improve by more aggressively revising reads after such a strong signal of multiple evils on his team.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, Iris had the tough job of sorting between Grace and Bob, and their leadership on mission 3 ended up with a failed team that included at least one evil. They seemed to trust their Merlin read somewhat but not decisively enough to anchor good’s consensus around the right core.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, Jack stayed just credible enough to be included on the crucial mission 4 team while not drawing overwhelming suspicion earlier. Their endgame positioning and final read on Merlin were strong, capitalizing well on the confusion sown by Morgana and Mordred.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too much on the successful first mission and was too slow to hard-clear Diana while pushing more aggressively on Alice and Bob after the double-fail on Mission 2. I did well at staying consistent with my logic in discussions, but I needed to be louder and more forceful in pointing out how damning that second mission result was.

player_observations.Alice: Very comfortable playing from an early trusted position; used the clean Mission 1 result to build long-term credibility and stayed calm under suspicion after Mission 2. Tends to vote in a way that keeps her on teams without drawing attention to herself.
player_observations.Bob: Played a strong partnered-evil role by blending in as a reasonable voice and not over-defending Alice, which made both of them harder to nail together. Tends to present logical-sounding arguments that slightly misdirect without being obviously agenda-driven.
player_observations.Charlie: Low-information, somewhat chaotic presence that made it harder to read alignment; this fit Oberon well because the confusion he created benefited evil. Often stayed just outside the center of logic-heavy discussions, which let him avoid tight scrutiny.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very solid, steady good game and maintained a consistent tone that should have earned more trust earlier. Willing to go on risky teams when needed, which is good for progress but makes her slightly harder to hard-clear if others aren’t tracking patterns carefully.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as generally sincere and collaborative, especially in mid-game discussions. Sometimes deferred a bit too much to stronger voices, which let evil narratives persist longer than they should have.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, did a good job not over-signaling but at times may have been too subtle in steering away from the evil cluster around Alice/Bob. Voting patterns and soft nudges made sense in hindsight but weren’t quite strong enough to overcome table uncertainty.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a straightforward good player, but his presence on the double-fail team made him an unfortunate collateral suspect. Tends to argue from immediate mission results rather than overarching role interactions, which can make him both convincing and misled.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, seemed genuinely torn between Grace and Bob/Alice at times, which is understandable given how well evil masked their roles. Tried to use voting and team preferences to resolve the Merlin identity but didn’t fully translate those reads into strong table pushes.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, stayed reasonably controlled and avoided being the primary focus of suspicion until late, which gave evil space to maneuver. On Mission 4, leaned into the fail outcome effectively to close the game and capitalize on the confusion already created.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I identified some evil patterns (like the double-fail on Mission 2 and the late-game composition on Mission 4) but I didn’t translate that info into clear, consistent signals for the team, especially Percival, and that let evil control the mission flow. I also played too cautiously in distancing from certain evils (especially Alice and Bob), which made it harder for good to form a trusted core and avoid the stacked failing teams.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortable sitting on early success (Mission 1) to build trust, then blending into larger, mixed teams where her presence was harder to challenge; she leveraged Mordred’s hidden-from-Merlin status well by not overreaching.
player_observations.Bob: Played a classic Morgana game by pairing with Alice and Henry on Mission 2 and hiding in the noise of a 4-person team with a double-fail; pattern suggests he likes being on pivotal mid-game missions where blame can be spread widely.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, created quiet chaos by being present on the crucial losing missions (3 and 4) without obvious coordination, which made his alignment harder to pin down and clouded team reads.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently willing to be on missions and took early trust from the success on Mission 1 into later proposals; her inclusion on failing teams made her look suspicious despite being good, showing she’s comfortable absorbing risk for the team.
player_observations.Eve: Played a low-key good game, joining mid/late missions (3 and 4) that failed, which unintentionally made her look like a possible coordinated evil; her style suggests she’s fine being a quiet, flexible pick rather than forcing herself into leadership.
player_observations.Frank: Despite being good and on both M1 (success) and M2 (double fail), he didn’t clearly project his perspective afterward, which let evil use the ambiguity around that mission to their advantage; tends to play more reactively than proactively.
player_observations.Henry: As a good leader on Mission 2, he took a risky, broad team that included both Alice and Bob, which opened the door for a heavy evil presence; he seems comfortable making bold, information-generating choices, even when they’re exploitable by evil.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she had a hard job distinguishing Merlin from Morgana given how the information played out around Missions 2 and 3; her mission 3 proposal shows she’s proactive and willing to commit to a read even under uncertainty.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, he steered the late-game by putting together Mission 4’s failing team, mixing good and evil well; his leadership shows a preference for high-impact, high-variance decisions and he capitalized on the confusion to secure the win.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on Frank and Diana after Mission 2’s double-fail and didn’t sufficiently re-evaluate when later missions pointed more strongly toward Alice/Bob/Jack. I also played too passively in table talk, letting evil narratives about Grace and Iris gain traction instead of clearly pushing a coherent good-world. Next time I should anchor more on team compositions across missions and track who keeps getting included on failing teams.

player_observations.Alice: Very comfortable staying on early successful teams and then quietly slipping onto failing ones; she played a convincing, low-key 'trusted core' Mordred that I didn’t scrutinize hard enough. Her calm presence and willingness to be on multiple mixed teams made her look generically good instead of specifically suspicious.
player_observations.Bob: Played Morgana aggressively but in a controlled way, often sounding like a 'helpful analyst' and subtly reinforcing suspicion on good players. His presence on the Mission 2 fail should have been a bigger red flag, but he blended his arguments well with the general table consensus.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, his slightly off-beat reads and occasional contradictions made him look like a confused good player rather than coordinated evil. I discounted his weirdness as inexperience/noise instead of recognizing that he didn’t line up cleanly with any consistent good-world.
player_observations.Diana: Looked suspicious to me mostly because she appeared on multiple failing missions, but her tone and logic were generally transparent and good-leaning. I should have weighted her mission 3 and 4 behavior (pushing reasonable teams and reactions to fails) more than simple team overlap.
player_observations.Eve: Played a straightforward, earnest good style, but I kept misreading her caution as possible evil hedging. Her reactions after mission fails were very consistent with a good player trying to puzzle things out, which I underappreciated in real time.
player_observations.Frank: Got heavily tied to my suspicions after the Mission 2 double-fail, partly because he was quiet at key points and didn’t strongly defend alternative worldviews. In hindsight, his lack of sharp agenda and his willingness to be sidelined from later teams was more consistent with confused good than with confident evil.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, she walked a careful line but sometimes got overruled or drowned out when evil narratives gained momentum. I misread her occasional hesitancy as uncertainty instead of as a Merlin trying not to over-direct, and I didn’t give her enough weight in team selection.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she had some good directional pushes but didn’t get enough buy-in from the table, and I didn’t trust her reads as strongly as I should have. When she and Grace were roughly aligned, that should have anchored me more firmly against the actual evil core.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, he positioned himself as a central, reasonable voice late game, and I let his confident framing sway me too much. His role in building or approving failing teams was clearer in hindsight, but in the moment his assertiveness read as leadership rather than manipulation.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly protected Grace as a likely Merlin early, but I tunneled too hard on Bob as the only fake Merlin and didn’t account for Mordred staying quiet in the shadows. I also didn’t update my reads quickly enough after Mission 2’s double fail and Mission 3’s single fail, so my team approvals didn’t reflect the strongest logic from the later information.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-drama evil game as Mordred, blending into the early successes and avoiding being a focal point of suspicion even after later fails.
player_observations.Bob: Leaned into an active, information-forward style that fit Morgana well, creating enough noise and apparent insight to be plausibly Merlin for much of the game.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off as erratic and slightly off-meta, which made reads on them difficult and let them benefit from being written off as just ‘weird good’ at points.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently made reasonable, logic-based contributions that aligned with good, but her involvement in failed missions created misleading suspicion around her.
player_observations.Eve: Played a fairly quiet but steady good role, generally aligning with logical team constructions but not forcefully pushing alternative narratives when suspicion rose.
player_observations.Frank: Felt very transparently good through tone and voting patterns, though that clarity didn’t translate into strongly steering the table away from bad team choices.
player_observations.Grace: Gave solid, subtly guided reads consistent with Merlin—often nudging the table in the right direction without overexposing herself, though evil ultimately capitalized on our misreads.
player_observations.Henry: Approached the game analytically and tried to reason through mission results, but the Mission 2 team choice (with two fails) heavily damaged his perceived credibility.
player_observations.Jack: As Assassin, stayed just involved enough to track claims and likely Merlin candidates while not drawing heavy suspicion, enabling a strong endgame position for the kill.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile as Assassin while still participating enough in discussions to avoid suspicion, and I helped solidify the narrative that the early fails came from mixed teams rather than a coordinated evil block. I could improve by more actively shaping late-game team choices and baiting a clearer, more confident Merlin reveal to make the final assassination decision even easier in future games.

player_observations.Alice: Very proactive as Mordred, jumping onto early teams and contributing to the layered suspicion around mid-game missions, which helped hide the full extent of the evil team.
player_observations.Bob: Played Morgana subtly, not over-claiming Merlin-type insight but inserting just enough reads to muddy the perception of who Merlin could be.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off a bit disconnected from coordinated evil logic, which actually helped sell them as a confused or middling-good player rather than hidden evil.
player_observations.Diana: Played straightforwardly, voting and speaking in a way that felt honest but perhaps a bit conservative, which made it easier for evil to keep her on mixed teams without strong resistance.
player_observations.Eve: Asked good, pointed questions but didn’t push hard enough to lock in a reliable trust circle, leaving room for evil to keep re-entering mission proposals.
player_observations.Frank: Seemed genuinely towny and consistent, but didn’t leverage that credibility aggressively to force safer team comps once multiple fails had appeared.
player_observations.Grace: As Merlin, gave reasonably accurate resistance to some bad teams but was careful enough that her identity stayed ambiguous, which ultimately left just enough doubt for a successful assassination.
player_observations.Henry: As a good leader on Mission 2, ended up with a heavily evil-leaning team; his team construction and subsequent reads gave evil a strong foothold early.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, tried to parse out Merlin vs. Morgana but didn’t narrow it decisively enough; their uncertainty gave cover to both Grace and Bob and made the final good team reads less coordinated.
